stream_context.summary: Kaze spends the stream inside Blender and the decomp repo finishing Course 11—currently nick-named “Oily Boily Bay,” Bowser’s corporate oil-rig tower.  He fine-tunes textures, vertex colors, and light fog on the main tower, mocks up the Bowser logo, and installs new HUD assets (health and breath meters) supplied by Biobak.  He also shows re-worked earlier courses, demonstrates revamped camera controls and tests real N64 performance.
level: Brief demo jumps to Course 1, 2, 8 for re-work showcase

development_findings.summary: Kaze completely rebuilt the 3-D ``Mario Bros 3`` retro section in Course 2, widening corridors, adding slides, improving camera and framerate.
development_findings.quote: The demo is so different from the final game… This one has been completely reworked.  The framerate is higher, the level is better.

development_findings.summary: New camera scheme: C-Left/Right now snap-rotate, D-pad holds for slow rotate, C-Up/Down and D-Up/Down for tilt; R centers camera.  Done after complaints about input lag.
development_findings.quote: We were complaining because of the slow control on the C button… hopefully this will feel a bit better to control.

development_findings.summary: HUD overhaul: power meter resized to 32×32, new eight-frame sprite set from Biobak; breath meter shortened and now animates with smooth scale-in/out and lerped fill.
development_findings.quote: You like how it scaled in, huh?… We gave it a pop-in and smooth fill and it looks so cool now.

development_findings.summary: Breath meter duration intentionally shorter than vanilla to prevent unrestricted underwater roaming unless player finds Koopa shells.
development_findings.quote: I don’t want the player to just feel free to roam everywhere until they are on a Koopa shell, so I wanted it shorter.

development_findings.summary: Course 11 structure: star 1 arena, minion strike zone, then upper area where Mario knocks Bowser’s head off; star 3 involves a giant owl-block that eats Mario via a grate trigger.
development_findings.quote: A cut-scene starts and the guy just comes by and eats you… so this would probably have to be a grate instead of a bucket.

development_findings.summary: Bowser Tower visuals: corporate office look, black/red palette, fog lighting tweaks; adding round Bowser emblem (128×64 mirrored) and octagonal bolt pattern suggested by Biobak/Zei­na.
Considering new microcode that disables near-clipping to solve camera issues.
development_findings.quote: I’ve been told about a new microcode today that we might want to use—the microcode allows you to disable near clipping.

development_findings.summary: Real N64 test reveals 20–30 FPS with current draw-order; plans to reorder geometry and disable clip-ratio debug flag.
development_findings.quote: We didn’t do any optimisation yet—this might be the worst possible draw order.

development_findings.summary: Multiplayer: Kaze wants to devote a two-week vacation (next month) to implement split-screen co-op, possibly via daily extended streams.
development_findings.quote: I get a two-week break from work… I was thinking of just doing a bunch of large streams—stairway—I’m making multiplayer in here.

development_findings.summary: Matrix-based animation remains core; Kaze laments modern devs ignoring matrix animation and explains why it’s efficient on N64.
development_findings.quote: That’s the thing that makes me so sad about modern video games… matrix animations are just so much better.

context_findings.summary: Programming philosophy: start with assembly before C; disregards formal tutorials and prefers project-driven learning.
context_findings.quote: Learning C before assembly is like explaining color to a blind person—you need to get vision first.

context_findings.summary: Workload: holds full-time job as professional game programmer, still works ~70-hour weeks including ROM-hack; has minor injury reducing workouts.
context_findings.quote: I don’t mind working 70-hour weeks—I’m kinda just a little different.

context_findings.summary: Strong personal vision; enjoys debate and remembers every detail, which can be challenging for collaborators.
context_findings.quote: I guess the biggest problem with working with me is that I do have a strong vision and I do like to argue.

context_findings.summary: Dislikes Windows 11 (“spyware”) and prefers Linux philosophically, yet stays on Windows 10 for compatibility.
context_findings.quote: Do I want even more Windows spyware?  No thank you.

context_findings.summary: Emotion: excited pride after HUD success; frustration with texture fog bug; playful banter over silly level names (“Oily Boily Bay”).
Personal life: rescued an injured baby bird with Zeina; planning social board-game outing later, so ends stream early.
context_findings.quote: We rescued a little baby bird today… It was kind of nice to see him all happy and ready to go.

biobak.summary: Provided new health/power meter sprite sheets (32×32, blue-to-green without brightness jump) and iterated colors with Kaze.
biobak.quote: Me and Biobak, we went through a lot of back and forth to get these colors exactly right.

biobak.summary: Modeled Buzzy Beetle enemy and draft Bowser tower emblem; suggested octagonal screw alignment.

zeina.summary: Offered design input for Bowser tower decoration (flags, Koopa shell, avoiding repetitive Bowser mouths).
Logistics support: discusses meal-prep and leaving house when Kaze plans marathon streams; casual on-stream presence.

key_stories.title: Reinventing the HUD
key_stories.summary: Community lag complaints spark a full redesign of camera controls and HUD.  Biobak sends new sprite sheets; Kaze rewrites rendering, adds smooth scaling and lerped fill, and verifies on real N64.
key_stories.challenge: Old HUD felt dated and obstructive; power-meter brightness was inconsistent and camera rotation lagged.
key_stories.process: Biobak drafts sprites; Kaze resizes textures, rewrites combine modes, adds scaling matrices, and live-tests.
key_stories.outcome: Cleaner, performance-friendly HUD and positive chat reaction; remaining to add sound cue and refine death-camera.
key_stories.key_quote: You like how it scaled in, huh?  That was so easy—oh my God I’m so good at this.

key_stories.title: Naming Course 11
key_stories.summary: Chat spends 30 minutes brainstorming Bowser oil-rig names; Kaze lands on the goofy rhyme “Oily Boily Bay,” keeps it as placeholder.
key_stories.challenge: Need a memorable, fitting level name.
key_stories.process: Rapid-fire suggestions; Kaze insists on rhyme/alliteration and Bowser theme.
key_stories.outcome: Temporary adoption of Oily Boily Bay; future name must be ‘at least better’.
key_stories.key_quote: I’m not accepting any name that’s not at least better than Oily Boily Bay.

key_stories.title: Baby Bird Rescue
key_stories.summary: Kaze and Zeina find an injured fledgling in the parking lot, nurse it overnight, and release it the next day.
key_stories.challenge: Bird unable to fly, vulnerable in parking lot.
key_stories.process: Zeina scoops bird, Kaze prepares box with towel, food, water; monitor overnight.
key_stories.outcome: Bird healthy and released; provides wholesome stream anecdote.
key_stories.key_quote: It was kind of nice to see him all happy and ready to go.
